{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3323993,"name":"Sam Richter","username":"Slink","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slink/{size}/172836_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T00:23:27.099Z","cooked":"

I just installed WPILib 2024.3.1 (my first wpilib 2024 install so version probably has nothing to do with the issue) and am attempting to simulate a C++ project but am running into this error:

FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

* What went wrong:
Execution failed for task ':compileFrcUserProgramWindowsx86-64DebugExecutableFrcUserProgramCpp'.
> Error while evaluating property 'compilerVersion' of task ':compileFrcUserProgramWindowsx86-64DebugExecutableFrcUserProgramCpp'.
   > No tool chain is available to build for platform 'windowsx86-64':
       - Tool chain 'visualCpp' (Visual Studio):
           - Could not locate a Visual Studio installation, using the command line tool, Windows registry or system path.
       - Tool chain 'roboRioGcc' (GNU GCC):
           - Don't know how to build for platform 'windowsx86-64'.

I found this thread but it seems to be different problem and nothing discussed pointed me to a solution:

Failed simulation build with desktop suppport enabled Technical Discussion
My team was invited to an off season rookie competition, but we decided that our old robot was going to be strip for parts. As a result, we might not have a physical robot to deploy and test our code in the future. I decided to test out the simulation feature as a alternative. To do so, I first used the official SimpleDifferentialDriveSimulation example here on GitHub. I look up so tutorial online, and I saw a command in command palette call Simulate Robot code on Desktop as seen in this pictu…

I am assuming that the issue has something to do with the fact that I have a preview version of Visual Studio currently installed (17.10.0 preview 1.0), but don’t know enough about the Gradle build extensions to know exactly why. I should also point out that other build tools like CMake have not had an issue finding my VS install.

Any pointers are much appreciated. Thank you in advance!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-05T00:36:39.244Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":217,"reads":34,"readers_count":33,"score":1086.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457285,"topic_slug":"c-project-simulation-unable-to-find-toolchain-visual-studio","display_username":"Sam Richter","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/failed-simulation-build-with-desktop-suppport-enabled/443739","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Failed simulation build with desktop suppport enabled","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49899,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3407 Programming Alum"},"post_url":"/t/c-project-simulation-unable-to-find-toolchain-visual-studio/457285/1","custom_user_title":"3407 Programming Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3324007,"name":"Thad House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T00:42:50.911Z","cooked":"

Gradle won’t find prerelease versions of VS. It also won’t find just the build tools if you installed those, it will only find full installs of VS.

I have a full install so is there any way to make it work with the prerelease version?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-05T00:44:34.621Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":29,"readers_count":28,"score":25.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457285,"topic_slug":"c-project-simulation-unable-to-find-toolchain-visual-studio","display_username":"Sam Richter","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16147,"username":"Thad_House","name":"Thad House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49899,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3407 Programming Alum"},"post_url":"/t/c-project-simulation-unable-to-find-toolchain-visual-studio/457285/3","custom_user_title":"3407 Programming Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3324013,"name":"Thad House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T00:48:11.124Z","cooked":"

Not an easy way, no. Internally it’s using vswhere, and they’re not passing in the flag to use prerelease versions. There are ways to past a custom compiler, but they’re complicated and not really reliable.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-05T00:48:11.124Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":29,"readers_count":28,"score":35.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457285,"topic_slug":"c-project-simulation-unable-to-find-toolchain-visual-studio","display_username":"Thad House","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49899,"username":"Slink","name":"Sam Richter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slink/{size}/172836_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16147,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Dev | 2025 VOTY"},"post_url":"/t/c-project-simulation-unable-to-find-toolchain-visual-studio/457285/4","custom_user_title":"WPILib Dev | 2025 VOTY","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3324042,"name":"Sam Richter","username":"Slink","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slink/{size}/172836_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-05T01:17:17.246Z","cooked":"

It appears there is an easy but somewhat inconvenient solution. After searching some Stack Overflow threads I stumbled upon the gradle toolchain documentation which shows how to specify the VS installation location for the visualCpp toolchain. I added this block to my build.gradle (inside model{}):

toolChains {
    visualCpp(VisualCpp) {
        installDir 'D:/Applications/Visual Studio 2022' // << VS install directory
    }
}

And now it works!
